761f2c76-4a0a-47c6-9243-d41c82dbb2ae.description: Online Educators Certification One. Teaching and Learning online. Using the Blackboard Learning Management System
761f2c76-4a0a-47c6-9243-d41c82dbb2ae.name: Online Educator Certificate 1

badge_template_activities.title: OEC 1 training focuses on the "how to" of Blackboard. The content in OEC 1 training includes: 1) Investigating the features of Blackboard 2) Understanding how the features of Blackboard work 3) Integrating the features of Blackboard into a useful module/folder for your course(s) 4) Producing a useful module/folder for your course(s) using design best practices.
Online Educator Certificate 2

1a88ecc6-4e55-4871-9364-a66aa2a73e4b.description: Online Educators Certification Two. Teaching and Learning online. Using the Blackboard Learning Management System and OEC 1 must be successfully completed before attempting OEC 2
1a88ecc6-4e55-4871-9364-a66aa2a73e4b.name: Online Educator Certificate 2

badge_template_activities.title: OEC 2 training focuses on the in depth policies of Blackboard. The content in OEC 2 training includes: 1)Constructing when to use best practices in course design 2)Designing best practices 3)Differentiating why to use design best practices and the purpose it serves within a course. 4)Implementing using design best practices in the creation of a useful module/folder for your course(s).

6310f70b-22e7-4222-8d5d-366be0185c8b.description: The classroom management badge provides pre-service or practicing teachers with evidence-based knowledge and skills to effectively manage classrooms at a variety of grade levels and in diverse settings. Competencies within the Classroom Management badge align with the Interstate Teacher Assessment and Support Consortium standards (InTASC).
6310f70b-22e7-4222-8d5d-366be0185c8b.name: Classroom Management

alignments.name: Learning Environments - InTASC 3
alignments.description: The teacher works with others to create environments that support individual and collaborative learning, and that encourage positive social interaction, active engagement in learning, and self-motivation.

alignments.name: Assessment - InTASC 6
alignments.description: The teacher uses multiple methods of assessment to engage learners in their own growth, monitor learner progress, and guide the teacher’s and learner’s decision-making.

alignments.name: Planning for Instruction - InTASC 7
alignments.description: The teacher plans instruction that supports every student in meeting rigorous learning goals by drawing upon knowledge of content areas, curriculum, cross-disciplinary skills, and pedagogy, as well as knowledge of learners and the community context.

alignments.name: Instructional Strategies - InTASC 8
alignments.description: The teacher uses a variety of instructional strategies to encourage learners to develop a deep understanding of content areas and their connections, and to build skills to apply knowledge in meaningful ways.

alignments.name: Professional Learning and Ethical Practice - InTASC 9
alignments.description: The teacher engages in ongoing professional learning and uses evidence to continually evaluate his/her practice, particularly the effects of his/her choices and actions on others (learners, families, other professionals, and the community), and adapts practice to meet the needs of each learner.

badge_template_activities.title: Complete EDUC 5283 Teaching Methods course with 80% competency, which is equal to a B in the course based on the following outcomes. The badge earner will be able to:
1) Analyze the effectiveness of classroom management strategies to support student learning [InTASC 3, 7].
2) Evaluate effective applications of measuring and monitoring student learning [InTASC 3, 6].
3) Implement instructional strategies to engage students in the learning process [InTASC 3, 7, 8].
4) Demonstrate reflective teaching practices [InTASC 6, 9].

ee91215d-afb1-49aa-9a5d-7abb61025173.description: The Differentiated Instruction Pedagogy badge provides pre-service or practicing teachers and instructional specialists with evidence-based instructional strategies to engage diverse learners in different learning environments. The badge emphasizes theory and philosophies of teaching, learning styles, instructional design, instructional techniques, and learning tasks with application to the improvement of teaching skills. Competencies align with InTasc standards.
ee91215d-afb1-49aa-9a5d-7abb61025173.name: Differentiated Instruction Pedagogy

alignments.name: Learning Differences - InTASC 2
alignments.description: The teacher uses understanding of individual differences and diverse cultures and communities to ensure inclusive learning environments that enable each learner to meet high standards.

alignments.name: Planning for Instruction - InTASC 7
alignments.description: The teacher plans instruction that supports every student in meeting rigorous learning goals by drawing upon knowledge of content areas, curriculum, cross-disciplinary skills, and pedagogy, as well as knowledge of learners and the community context.

alignments.name: Professional Learning and Ethical Practices - InTASC 9
alignments.description: The teacher engages in ongoing professional learning and uses evidence to continually evaluate his/her practice, particularly the effects of his/her choices and actions on others (learners, families, other professionals, and the community), and adapts practice to meet the needs of each learner.

badge_template_activities.title: Complete EDUC 5463 Differentiated Instructional Strategies course with 80% competency, which is equal to a B in the course based on the following outcomes. The badge earner will be able to:
1) Demonstrate an understanding of differentiation theory and practice [InTASC 2].
2) Analyze differentiated instructional frameworks [InTASC 2].
3) Evaluate current differentiated instructional practices [InTASC 9].
Design component- and content-specific differentiated instruction [InTASC 7].

3a023590-03f9-40ad-acaf-c954efd8ea6b.description: The Brain-Based Pedagogy badge provides pre-service or practicing teachers and instructional specialists with evidence-based knowledge and skills to effectively incorporate and apply brain-compatible techniques that address learners' motivational needs. Competencies align with InTasc standards.
3a023590-03f9-40ad-acaf-c954efd8ea6b.name: Brain-Based Pedagogy

alignments.name: Learner Development - InTASC 1
alignments.description: The teacher understands how learners grow and develop, recognizing that patterns of learning and development vary individually within and across the cognitive, linguistic, social, emotional, and physical areas, and designs and implements developmentally appropriate and challenging learning experiences.

alignments.name: Learning Environments - InTASC 3
alignments.description: The teacher works with others to create environments that support individual and collaborative learning, and that encourage positive social interaction, active engagement in learning, and self-motivation.

alignments.name: Content Knowledge - InTASC 4
alignments.description: The teacher understands the central concepts, tools of inquiry, and structures of the discipline(s) he or she teaches and creates learning experiences that make these aspects of the discipline accessible and meaningful for learners to assure mastery of the content.

alignments.name: Application of Content - InTASC - 5
alignments.description: The teacher understands how to connect concepts and use differing perspectives to engage learners in critical thinking, creativity, and collaborative problem solving related to authentic local and global issues.

badge_template_activities.title: Complete the EDUC 5683 Brain-Based Learning course with 80% competency, which is equal to a B in the course based on the following outcomes. The badge earner will be able to:
Demonstrate knowledge of a brain-based learning environment [InTASC 1].
Create brain-compatible learning environments [InTASC 5].
Design brain-compatible curriculum [InTASC 3].
Evaluate brain-compatible curriculum [InTASC 4].

29d1ad09-25a6-40da-8efc-81eeb376c28c.description: The Learner-Centric Pedagogy badge provides pre-service or practicing teachers and instructional specialists with evidence-based knowledge and skills to effectively engage in active, learner-centered teaching techniques. Competencies align with InTasc standards.
29d1ad09-25a6-40da-8efc-81eeb376c28c.name: Learner-Centric Pedagogy

alignments.name: Learner Development - InTASC 1
alignments.description: The teacher understands how learners grow and develop, recognizing that patterns of learning and development vary individually within and across the cognitive, linguistic, social, emotional, and physical areas, and designs and implements developmentally appropriate and challenging learning experiences.

alignments.name: Learning Differences - InTASC 2
alignments.description: The teacher uses understanding of individual differences and diverse cultures and communities to ensure inclusive learning environments that enable each learner to meet high standards.

alignments.name: Learning Environments - InTASC 3
alignments.description: The teacher works with others to create environments that support individual and collaborative learning, and that encourage positive social interaction, active engagement in learning, and self motivation.

alignments.name: Content Knowledge - InTASC 4
alignments.description: The teacher understands the central concepts, tools of inquiry, and structures of the discipline(s) he or she teaches and creates learning experiences that make these aspects of the discipline accessible and meaningful for learners to assure mastery of the content.

badge_template_activities.title: Complete the EDUC 5633 Cognitive Learning Styles course with 80% competency, which is equal to a B in the course based on the following outcomes. The badge earner will be able to:
Demonstrate how learning styles curriculum can increase student equity, engagement, and understanding [InTASC 1 and 3].
Create a learning styles curriculum that can be utilized for at-risk learners [InTASC 2 and 4].
Design learner-centric strategies to implement in learning styles classrooms [InTASC 2 and 3].
Evaluate learner-centric curriculum [InTASC 4].

38ce8ddb-5491-4319-8c60-5f1b0aaf6b29.description: Earners of the Classroom Teaching Certificate badge have developed advanced competency in theory, methods, and the practice of teaching, classroom management, unit and lesson plan development, assessment, and differentiated instruction techniques.
38ce8ddb-5491-4319-8c60-5f1b0aaf6b29.name: Classroom Teaching Certificate

alignments.name: InTASC Model Core Teaching Standards
alignments.description: This certificate focuses on inTASC standards 1-9

badge_template_activities.title: Complete the following courses with 80% competency, which is equal to a B in the course based on the following outcomes. The badge earner will be able to: 1) Identify contemporary approaches in the knowledge base of theories of motivation. 2) Demonstrate reflective teaching practices. 3) Reflect on the impact of educational psychology as a tool for understanding the teaching and learning process.

EDUC 5283 Teaching Methods: Interpreting the theory and knowledge bases of education, presenting instructional materials and teaching for the diverse classroom, assessing resource materials, writing objectives to teach across the curriculum, using teaching tools, assessing student performance, applying motivational techniques, critiquing and utilizing classroom management effectively, and demonstrating teaching strategies will be included.

EDUC 5463 Differentiated Instructional Strategies: Explore differentiated instructional strategies and an analysis of selected instructional strategies with an emphasis on theory and philosophy of teaching, learning styles, instructional innovations, instructional techniques, and learning tasks with application to the improvement of teaching skills.
EDUC 5633 Cognitive Learning Styles: Explore active learning, learner-centric teaching techniques, and strategies for designing and implementing curriculum through the learning styles perspective.

EDUC 5683 Brain-Based Learning: Explore the latest research on the brain and its implications for instruction by incorporating brain-compatible techniques that address students’ basic motivational needs. Learners discover how to apply underlying principles and instructional practice to enhance the brain-compatible classroom.

086efb26-6e86-40ad-8111-ebdbd35806c7.description: After the completion of all four Crime Scene Investigator (CSI) levels, badge earners will obtain a Crime Scene Investigator Certificate from Northeastern State University (NSU) and the Oklahoma State Bureau of Investigation (OSBI). Badge earners can document the crime scenes, take photographs and physical measurements of the scene, identify and collect forensic evidence, and maintain the proper chain of custody of that evidence.
086efb26-6e86-40ad-8111-ebdbd35806c7.name: Crime Scene Investigation (Non-Credit Course)

alignments.name: Standards
alignments.description: They may be called in to court to justify evidence collected. Analytical Skills Crime scene investigators, or CSIs, have elite analytical skills. The analytical skills forensic definitions mean they have an ability to survey a crime scene, formulate theories on how the different pieces of evidence work together and follow-up on key details.

alignments.name: Outcomes
alignments.description: Accurate and complete collection of appropriate evidence toward effective use to deduce crime situations. Learning of obtaining, photographing, and preserving evidence at a crime scene. Encourages an understanding of crime scene investigation, that is crucial for a forensic scientist to further analyze the crime and suspect.

alignments.name: Outcomes
alignments.description: Develop an understanding of the scientific principles of crime scene investigation and reconstruction, including evidence collection and preservation. Demonstrate the capabilities, use, potential and limitations of forensic laboratory theory and techniques in respect to the analysis of evidence.

alignments.name: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATOR I
alignments.description: This helps when working with other officers and the district attorney to formulate the motive and the likely way in which t he crime transpired. Attorneys need to tell stories in court to persuade judges and juries on how to view the evidence. Investigators take notes and prepare formal case reports prosecutors use in court cases.

alignments.name: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATOR I
alignments.description: Poise and Tact A key quality for crime scene investigators is poise under pressure. Problem-Solving Instincts Top crime scene investigators are natural problem-solvers. They combine science aptitude, analytical skills and critical thinking to piece together evidence and testimony.

alignments.name: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATOR II
alignments.description: In some larger communities or in high-profile cases, you may have to stay poised with media and citizens hovering nearby as well. In essence, forensic science careers try to develop stories based on their interpretations of evidence and theories of circumstantial events.

alignments.name: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATOR II
alignments.description: CSIs periodically investigate horrible crime scenes involving brutal murders and lots of blood, according to Crime Scene Investigator Network. You must have a strong stomach to last in this line of work. More importantly, you need to remain calm and focused on evidence-gathering, even while working around a horrific scene.

alignments.name: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATOR III
alignments.description: The CSI usually helps get the crime scene cordoned off to avoid disrupting evidence. You also discuss the evidence with other police offers to piece together the evidence and statements gathered from witnesses. CSIs also occasionally serve as expert witnesses to lay out the crime scene in a court case. Written skills are critical as well.

alignments.name: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATOR III
alignments.description: You need a strong scientific acumen and working knowledge of the various evidence-gathering chemicals and devices for this profession. While the CSI doesn't conduct all of the evidence-gathering, he orders various tests and keeps track of all of the results.

alignments.name: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATOR IV
alignments.description: Communication Skills Skills needed to be a forensic investigator include excellent communication skills. When investigating, you often lead a team of lab techs and other law enforcement officers.

badge_template_activities.title: CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATOR I - 1) Overview and theory of CSI 2) Crime scene management 3) Legal considerations of CSI 4) Crime scene search patterns 5) Collection and packaging of evidence - DICED 6) Crime scene sketching and diagramming 7) Latent print processing.
CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATOR II - 1) DNA 2) Body as a crime scene 3) Wound recognition 4) Fire scene investigation 5) Crime scene photography.
CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATOR III - 1) Bloodstain pattern analysis 2) Trajectory analysis.
CRIME SCENE INVESTIGATOR IV - 1) Process mock crime scene using learned processes 2) Complete crime scene report 3) Moot court.

d3b19fce-1c94-42aa-b610-94543ae30ab5.description: The Geographic Information Systems (GIS) Certificate program provides broad exposure to GIS principles and applications. Badge earners will be well-versed in general GIS theory and will have practical exposure to the following: 1) GIS hardware and software, 2) spatial databases planning/construction, 3) GIS analyses, and 4) data mapping and visualization.
d3b19fce-1c94-42aa-b610-94543ae30ab5.name: GIS Certificate Level 1

badge_template_activities.title: This GIS Certificate requires students to complete the following courses earning a minimum of a 70% in all required competencies. The badge earner will be able to: 1) Apply the principles of geographic information science 2) Formulate requirements and constraints for spatial analysis 3) Complete spatial analysis using selected GIS software packages 4) Design and implement real-world GIS applications 5) Communicate effectively using maps and other graphic presentation formats.

GEOG 3813 - Geographic Information Systems: Introduction to GIS as a decision-support system using spatially-referenced data. Provides experience with GIS software in environmental and social science applications.
GEOG 4053 - Cartography: Students learn cartographic theories, techniques used to collect and analyze data, and the design and construction of maps, with an emphasis on thematic maps.

GEOG 4803 - Geospatial Technologies: Students learn about global navigation satellite systems (GNSS) and remote sensing and how to integrate these technologies into Geographic Information System (GIS) projects.

GEOG 4833 - Advanced GIS: Applied problem-solving using geographic information systems (GIS). Employs advanced spatial analysis capabilities of GIS software with 2D and 3D data. Particular attention is given to transportation networks, terrain surfaces, and marketing data.
GEOG 4853 - GIS Automation and Scripting: Students learn to use GIS scripting languages and other techniques to perform spatial analysis, automate tasks, and develop custom extensions.
GEOG 4873 - GIS Applications: Students apply spatial analytical techniques and modeling to geographical problem solving in business, urban planning, natural resource management, and other fields.

ff01623a-4856-4049-bf4a-13450e06a199.description: Students will acquire in-depth knowledge of health care informatics which is the intersection of information science, computer science, quantitative analysis and health care. Students will learn about the resources, devices, and methods required to optimize the acquisition, storage, retrieval, and use of information in health and biomedicine. Students will gain experience with health informatics tools including computer programs, analysis tools, clinical guidelines, formal medical terminologies,
ff01623a-4856-4049-bf4a-13450e06a199.name: Advanced Healthcare Informatics

alignments.name: SLO 1
alignments.description: Interpret health information standards.

alignments.name: SLO 2
alignments.description: Advocate information operability and information exchange.

alignments.name: SLO 3
alignments.description: Evaluate health information systems and data storage design.

alignments.name: SLO 4
alignments.description: Manage clinical indices/databases/registries.

alignments.name: SLO 5
alignments.description: Apply knowledge of database architecture and design to meet organizational needs.

alignments.name: SLO 6
alignments.description: Analyze legal concepts and principles to the practice of HIM.

alignments.name: SLO 7
alignments.description: Analyze privacy, security and confidentiality policies and procedures for internal and external use and exchange of health information.

alignments.name: SLO 8
alignments.description: Protect electronic health information through confidentiality and security measures, policies and procedures.

alignments.name: SLO 9
alignments.description: Utilize technology for data collection, storage, analysis, and reporting of information.

alignments.name: SLO 10
alignments.description: Evaluate administrative reports using appropriate software.

alignments.name: SLO 11
alignments.description: Apply analytical results to facilitate decision-making.

alignments.name: SLO 12
alignments.description: Apply data extraction methodologies.

alignments.name: SLO 13
alignments.description: Recommend organizational action based on knowledge obtained from data exploration and mining.

alignments.name: SLO 14
alignments.description: Analyze clinical data to identify trends that demonstrate quality, safety, and effectiveness of healthcare.

badge_template_activities.title: Instructional strategies include: audio visual materials, discussion, computer-based training, practical exercises, lectures.

63a52513-9472-4dd8-ba3f-7e1edc92538a.description: Students will gain a basic understanding of health care informatics including computer hardware, network architecture, clinical application of electronic health records, and health care software applications. Students will apply informatics knowledge to relevant regulatory, patient privacy, security, and reimbursement concepts in the study of current trends and emerging issues in health care.
63a52513-9472-4dd8-ba3f-7e1edc92538a.name: Introduction to Health Informatics

alignments.name: SLO 1
alignments.description: Develop knowledge about problems and challenges that health informatics addresses

alignments.name: SLO 2
alignments.description: Apply basic knowledge to the research and practice of health informatics

alignments.name: SLO 3
alignments.description: Demonstrate basic skills and knowledge in health informatics for application in future health-related careers

alignments.name: SLO 4
alignments.description: Demonstrate ability to ask, search for information, and answer health-related questions

alignments.name: SLO 5
alignments.description: Demonstrate ability to identify genomic variants associated with a disease phenotype and communicate this association

alignments.name: SLO 6
alignments.description: Perform visualization and simple analysis of a data set to assess difficulty of predicting cardiovascular risk in a synthetic patient dataset

alignments.name: SLO 7
alignments.description: Apply communication skills through an interview with an informatics professional and development of a written summary

alignments.name: SLO 8
alignments.description: Analyze ethical and diversity issues in health informatics

badge_template_activities.title: Instructional strategies include: audio visual materials, discussion, computer-based training, practical exercises, lectures.
